task:
Task:
  The response selects or isolates information already present without introducing new content.
constraints: Completeness ("max"): The response is as exhaustive as reasonable, covering essentially everything relevant and treating omissions as errors.
Scope ("struct"): The response focuses on how things are arranged or related—dependencies, coordination, constraints, incentives, or organizing patterns.
Method ("systemic"): The response analyses the subject as a whole system, including components, boundaries, flows, and feedback loops.
Form ("contextualise"): The response adds or reshapes context to support another operation—such as supplying background for an LLM or reframing content—without rewriting the main text itself.
Channel ("sync"): The response takes the shape of a synchronous or live session plan (agenda, steps, cues) rather than static reference text.
Directional ("fip rog"): The response moves between abstract principles and concrete examples while examining structural patterns and reflecting on what they reveal.
